sn42.6:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nālandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
sn42.6:4.2: Then Asibandhaka’s son the chief went up to the Buddha,
sn42.6:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn42.6:5.1: “Sir, there are western brahmins draped with moss who carry pitchers, immerse themselves in water, and worship the sacred flame.
sn42.6:5.2: When someone has died, they truly lift them up, raise them up, and guide them along to heaven.
sn42.6:5.3: But what about the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha: is he able to ensure that the whole world will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm when their body breaks up, after death?”
sn42.6:6.1: “Well then, brahmin, I’ll ask you about this in return,
sn42.6:6.2: and you can answer as you like.
sn42.6:7.1: What do you think, chief? Take a person who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s lying, divisive, harsh, and meaningless. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
sn42.6:7.2: And a large crowd comes together to offer up prayers and praise, circumnambulating them with cupped hands and saying:
sn42.6:7.3: ‘When this person’s body breaks up, after death, may they be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm!’
sn42.6:7.4: What do you think, chief? Would that person be reborn in heaven because of their prayers?”
sn42.6:8.1: “Chief, suppose a person was to throw a large rock into a deep lake.
sn42.6:8.2: And a large crowd was to come together to offer up prayers and praise, circumnambulating it with cupped hands, and saying:
sn42.6:8.3: ‘Rise, good rock! Float, good rock! Float to shore, good rock!’
sn42.6:8.4: What do you think, chief? Would that large rock rise up or float because of their prayers?”
sn42.6:8.6: “In the same way, take a person who kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s lying, divisive, harsh, and meaningless. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
sn42.6:8.7: Even though a large crowd comes together to offer up prayers and praise …
sn42.6:8.8: when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
sn42.6:9.1: What do you think, chief? Take a person who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s lying, divisive, harsh, or meaningless. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.
sn42.6:9.2: And a large crowd comes together to offer up prayers and praise, circumnambulating them with cupped hands and saying:
sn42.6:9.3: ‘When this person’s body breaks up, after death, may they be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell!’
sn42.6:9.4: What do you think, chief? Would that person be reborn in hell because of their prayers?”
sn42.6:10.1: “Chief, suppose a person was to sink a pot of ghee or oil into a deep lake and break it open.
sn42.6:10.2: Its shards and chips would sink down,
sn42.6:10.3: while the ghee or oil in it would rise up.
sn42.6:10.4: And a large crowd was to come together to offer up prayers and praise, circumnambulating it with cupped hands and saying:
sn42.6:10.5: ‘Sink, good ghee or oil! Descend, good ghee or oil! Go down, good ghee or oil!”
sn42.6:10.6: What do you think, chief? Would that ghee or oil sink and descend because of their prayers?”
sn42.6:11.1: “In the same way, take a person who doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s lying, divisive, harsh, or meaningless. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view. Even though a large crowd comes together to offer up prayers and praise …
sn42.6:11.2: when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”
sn42.6:11.3: When he said this, Asikabandha’s son the chief said to the Buddha:
sn42.6:11.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
